chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.To find out more, visit our website.

Well, I don't know if it's my favourite but there is a word I really like saying out loud – nincompoop. It means a silly person.For me, it's the taste of coffee and the smell of lavender or freshly baked bread.Our favourite tastes, smells and colours are controlled by our five senses – sight, sound, smell, taste and touch. For most of us, they don't mix. We see colours and taste flavours but we can't taste

sounds.But that's not how everyone's brain works.Imagine being able to taste every word that you hear.In this programme, we'll meet two sisters from Glasgow in Scotland who can do just that.And as usual, we'll learn some new vocabulary as well.

We'll hear more from the unusual sisters later but first I have a question for you, Neil.We've just heard what happens when Jen McCready hears the names Sophia and Leo but what does she taste when she hears the name Neil?
Well, I don't know what this says about me, Sam, but I'm going to guess that it's a jam sandwich.Okay, don't worry, Neil.I'll reveal the answer later in the programme.

There could be as many as 150 different types of synesthesia.For the Scottish sisters, having synesthesia is a gift – something Jen explained when she talked with BBC World Service programme The Food Chain.
There's still much doctors don't know about why some people

use synesthesia while most of us experience each sense in isolation.But it's clear that for Julie and Jen, synesthesia makes the world a more interesting, colourful place.Someone who can explain why so little is known about synesthesia is Guy Lechziner, consultant neurologist at King's College London and author of the book The Man Who Tasted Words.Here he is speaking to BBC World Service's The Food Chain.

Guy says that in the past, synesthesia was often dismissed, considered unimportant or uninteresting.Synesthetes were labelled people with overactive imaginations, a tendency to imagine things that are not true.

This research is showing that the cause of synesthesia could run in the family.Julie and Jen's brothers don't have synesthesia, but Jen's daughter does.And with an estimated 4% of the world population having some form of sense mixing, a world of new and exciting possibilities is opening up to millions.

Okay, well, I guess that Neil tastes like a jam sandwich.Was I right?Well, Neil, no, you don't taste like a jam sandwich.In fact, when Jen hears the name Neil, she tastes spaghetti hoops.Oh, well, it could be worse.The name Robert makes Jen taste rotten eggs.Sorry to any Roberts listening.Okay, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned in this programme about synesthesia, a neurological condition where two or more

senses mix together.A nincompoop is an informal way of saying a silly person.A craving for something is the strong desire to have it.A vivid sensation is clear, strong and detailed in your mind.When something is dismissed, it's considered unimportant or uninteresting.And finally, an overactive imagination is the tendency to imagine things that are not true.
We hope you'll join us again next time for more chat, interesting
